speaker: Democratic Debate. But I Would Like To Think Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nehl)
theText: Christmas Island Act-Casino Control OrdinancePublic Service Act-Determinations 1997 Nos. 15, Appointment of Administrator of Casino Oper16, 17, 18. ations, 7 May 1997 Taxation Administration ActCivil Aviation Act-Civil Aviation RegulationsDetermination 1997 No. TD 14. Exemptions 1997 Nos. 451FRS, 46/FRS, 471FRS. Ruling 1997 No. TR 12. Income Tax Assessment Act-RHQ company determinations 1997 No.4. Thursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5899 Thursday, 19 June 1997 Consideration in Detail Consideration resumed from 18 June. Department of Health and Family Services Department of Social Security together Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs Attorney-General's Department Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories together Department of Communications and the Arts Department of Administrative Services Department of Health and Family Services Proposed expenditure $2,879,850,000 that I touched on very quickly yesterday and that is questioning the commitment of this government to the national drug strategy and providing Australians with the best policies possible to combat the illegal drug trade in this country. I do so because I was struck yesterday by what I believed was the total and utter disinterest displayed by the Minister for Health (Dr Wooldridge) when he got up to answer some of the questions raised by us on this side of the House. He responded quite clearly and, I believe, quite precisely to all of the matters raised by myself and my colleagues in the debate surrounding his health portfolio, but he studiously avoided responding to any of my comments regarding the pitiful amount of money the government has now set aside for the national drugs strategy in this budget. The minister also refused to comment on the growing amount of calls for a national drug summit. In relation to the national drug strategy, I will not shrink from admitting that the program has had a real reduction in budgetary support almost every year since it was initiated by the Hawke Labor government in 1985. It is a disappointment and I do not deny that. What concerns me, however, is that at a time when Australia is awash with drugs, or more precisely when it is sinking under the weight of the drug trade, particularly heroin, we can little afford further cuts to the national drug strategy. It displays a total and utter disregard for our current predicament. It is either that, or it is because this government is simply blase or unaware of the scale of the drug emergency which our country now faces. Reducing the funding for the national drug strategy to $33 million, as indicated here in the appropriation bills, when close to $4 billion is taken in by government in excise and taxes on tobacco and alcohol-something I brought up again yesterday-is really a contemptuous joke. To quote the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), the Minister for Health's learned medical colleague, it is completely 'tokenistic'.
title: Slorc Each Time A Cameraman Appeared Where Action Must Be Taken To Secure The

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nehl) Took The Chair At 9.45 A.m.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mrs Crosio (Prospect) (9.45 A.m.)
theText: I will be brief. I would like to return to a subject5900 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 It makes me want to tear my hair out when I see that, in the past fortnight, three more people have died of drug overdoses on the streets of my community. As I said yesterday, kids of 11 and 12 are now shooting up in our car parks, our public toilets and our back alleyways, yet this government is allocating $1 billion to what I can only describe as whistles and balloons for our federation celebrations and only $33 million to help save people from the ravages of drugs, both legal and illegal. It is an absolute disgrace. I believe that while the Minister for Health was ducking the government's commitment to the national drugs strategy, he was also studiously avoiding responding to calls I made during the debate in detail for a national drugs summit; calls, I might add, which have been made with increased urgency not only by myself but also by various other individuals and organisations around this country. By other individuals and groups, I mean the directors of public prosecutions of New South Wales, Tasmania, South Australia and Victoria; the Australian Medical Association; the Royal Australian College of Physicians and various members of this House, on both sides of the parliament, I might add. I must admit I was quite shocked when I read in the Australian yesterday that a spokesperson for the Minister for Health responded to the Australian Medical Association's call for a national drug summit by saying such a meeting would be nothing but a 'talkfest' and would achieve 'zilch'. I believe that is disgraceful arrogance from the minister's office. The minister may want to have a chat to his spokesperson about 'talkfests'. While people are dying from drug related deaths at record levels, not just in Cabramatta, but all over Australia. I said yesterday during this debate that something like 1,182 people died in 1995the government has no problems spending that $40 million on the ultimate in talkfests, the constitutional convention. Meanwhile, our Minister for Health and our Prime Minister( Mr Howard) cannot see fit to providing the impetus to solving our nation's terrible drug tragedy by convening a national summit. They just cannot see how a national summit would provide national consensus, would plot new directions and would produce new strategies to deal with this drug problem. I say to the minister that I do not make this request for petty political purposes. I do not make this request in order to make him or the government look bad. I make this request because I am sick of seeing kids in my area and young adults throughout south-western Sydney destroying their lives and the lives of their families because of heroin abuse. The nation's current drug policies have failed. They are not about to get better. I put it again to the Minister for Health that discussing the recent evaluation of the national drug strategy at the Australasian Police Ministers Council and the Australian Health Ministers Conference in July this year will at best lead to change of the most marginal variety. We need dramatic change. The only way we are going to achieve that dramatic change on a national level, with national consensus, is via a national drug summit. The onus is now on the Minister for Health and particularly on the Prime Minister to swallow their misgivings and to take this step. I want to make it clear again that I am not saying that Australia's drug problem began on 2 March last year. I am not apportioning blame in regard to why Australia is currently being swamped by heroin-heroin of a level of purity never seen before in this country. WhatI am saying is that the coalition is in government now, and now is the time we need action. I repeat: the Minister for Health and the Prime Minister must act. It is not going to come about from the measly $33 million allocated to drug education in this budget. Thursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5901 consideration in detail we often tend to look at the economic side of government department spending, but I think we need to look at the human side as well. I want to speak about a letter I received from the Coburg Carers Association, from Mr Robert Laherty, who had been asked to write to the state government by members of his group because his committee had dealt with what they referred to as 'the usual complaints' the association heard: ... regarding lack of support facilities, home help cut to once a month, the abolition of almost all respite care, no respite care for carers at all, and the cut back in almost every aspect nf assistance for peap. caring for loved ones at home. He goes on to say: The Federal Government has certainly not helped our situation with the new nursing home "entrance fees" which has caused enormous fear and trauma to our older members tending to the needs of their lifetime partners, along with rises in prescription charges and a certain lack of awareness of our problemsHe also says: What we are concerned with is a lack of services at our public hospitals due to staff shortages and a curtailing of services offered by them due to the actions of your government. Referring to the Premier of Victoria, Mr Laherty goes on to say: On 26/1 0/96, you were featured on the front of our morning paper with the promise of millions of dollars for people in the position of carers. Our questions are these: when are we going to see any of it???? We don't want you to send us any glossy brochures telling us what you are going to do ...... We want to see what you are actually doing. We don't want to hear about committees and inquiries.... We want to know what if any new programs have begun? If so in what area???? Will councils be given access to this money for services to us?? .. What are you doing? Has any of the money been spent yet? ..... If so on what? Our council home help has been slashed to once a month. Two hours once a month is an absolute disgrace. Do not tell us it is local government business ... Your government devastated our local government with commissioners and cost cutting ... We spend our lives trying to provide love and all the basic human needs to our loved ones. We love them, wash them, feed them and try to treat them with dignity and respect. He concludes by saying: Your government policies and cost cutting are making our lives a complete and utter misery. That is the perspective of the Coburg Carers Association. We have heard the expression about uncaring people that they would 'sell their mothers to earn a dollar' . But what we have here, in the aged care changes, is the proposal that we should sell our mothers' homes in order to save the Howard government a dollar. You could be excused for thinking that this was an episode out of that wonderful series Mother and Son where the spineless son, Robert, endlessly worms his way out of his responsibility to his aged and confu-ed mother. In recent times we have seen concerns expressed by the Australian Catholic Health Care Association where they labelled the minister's latest proposal of a $5 a day subsidy for financially disadvantaged residents a 'cruel joke' . We have had Aged Care Australia urging the government to delay passage of its aged care legislation until there has been a full disclosure of critical information and additional funding for the proposals. In the electorate of Wills, the impact of this, which could possibly lead to closure by church and community groups of their nursing home beds, would be disastrous. There are currently about 380 beds available in Wills, of which 15 per cent are operated by church and community
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Kelvin Thomson (Wills) (9.51 A.m. )
theText: In consideration of estimates and5902 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 groups. That number needs to increase as the population ages, but it needs to increase in an affordable way. In Wills, 14.3 per cent of the population is aged 65 or older. This is well above the average. Among 148 federal electorates, Wills ranks 30th in terms of aged population. At the same time, the electorate of Wills is not an affluent electorate: average median income there is $33,000-odd, considerably less than the national average. In Wills, there are hostel and nursing home operations confronted with that scenario of an older than average population with a growing need for facilities; yet the minister is seeking to off-load that government responsibility on to the community. I believe it will have a very adverse affect on nursing home standards in Wills and that, indeed, the aged care changes will diminish and threaten the already stressed standards in terms of aged care that we have in our area. Proposed expenditure agreed to. Department of Social Security Proposed expenditure-$1,584,755,000-agreed to. Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs Proposed expenditure-$523,395,000-agreed to. Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs Proposed expenditure-$2,400,635,000. express some concern about the cut in funding for labour market programs. In doing that, I would like to contrast the attitude of the previous Labor government with the attitude of the coalition government in its response to the high unemployment with which both governments were confronted. The Labor government's response to unemployment was to introduce a program of job creation and training under the Working Nation program. They attacked the problem in two ways by setting a number of targets. Firstly, they had a program of creating some 500,000 jobs in the last term of the Labor government. In fact, they exceeded that program by creating over 700,000 jobs in that period. The second target that the government set itself was to reduce unemployment to five per cent by the year 2000. I believe that that government showed some character. It was prepared to put its reputation on the line by making those two commitments to reducing unemployment. By doing that, of course, there was more possibility that unemployment would be reduced. However, the current government has failed to do this. It has failed to set targets of any description in relation to reducing unemployment-other than, of course, cutting $1.8 billion from labour market programs, which is my basic concern in this presentation. But they have also asked the Australian people to be patient. First we were told that the reforms to the workplace reform legislation and the unfair dismissal legislation were going to create jobs. I recall very vividly, in the debate over last year's budget, coalition member after coalition member speaking in relation to the unfair dismissal provisions, as if that were going to be a cure-all for all our problems. Now we quite clearly see that the unfair dismissal legislation has been changed, yet there has been no alteration other than, in fact, an increase in unemployment. The Australian people have been asked to be patient and they are still waiting.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Mossfield (Greenway) (9.57 A.m.)
theText: In speaking on this aspect of expenditure, IThursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5903 We are now being asked to wait a little longer for a range of government policies to be introduced, including the GST, before the Australian people can expect any fall in unemployment. I think the danger that we all face is that we could see an improvement in the economy in many ways but a further decrease in unemployment. In other words, we could have a jobless recovery. I think this is very much a probability under this current government's policies, where it is not prepared to target job creation in many ways. In fact, all the indications are that unemployment is likely to grow during the remaining term of this government. Let me give you a few examples. A further 16,500 public service jobs will be lost in 1997-98. The defence efficiency review will mean a loss of a further 8,000 jobs, including many in regional Australia. There is restructuring in the private sector, in Telstra, Bums Philp and CSR. With BHP, we will see some 2,500 jobs disappear with no apparent concern or action by this current government. Employment in the manufacturing industry, which has been a great employer of Australians for many years, is now extremely t1at. We are expecting further cutbacks in banking and in the financial sector. Mr Paul Orton, the New South Wales based policy manager for the Australian Business Chamber, has been quoted in the press recently as saying that most investment 'means reducing rather than increasing jobs'. I emphasise: it means a reduction rather than an increase in jobs. I certainly do not believe the government is focused enough on job creation in this budget. I think a lot more finance could have been made available to help community based organisations and other organisations create jobs. The fact is that Australia's unemployed people just simply cannot wait any longer. They need relief now, not in a year or in two years. Last week's labour force figures showed a loss of 40,300 jobs in one month. (Time expired) I have major concerns with the government's direction on the issues. I refer specifically to what I regard as a non-solution to the question of creating jobs and the issue of work for the dole, which is not a real solution to the question of unemployment. I believe that youth unemployment is a major problem in Australia. But what is required is a budget strategy that is aimed at creating real jobs rather than pointing the finger, especially at the young unemployed on the basis that they are to be blamed for being unemployed, and coming up with policy options which are aimed at punishing young unemployed and their parents. I refer not just to the issues covered by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs-namely, the dole diary and work for the dole-but also to the announcements this week about the youth allowance, which was worked out by agreement between DEETYA and the Department of Social Security. I regard it as highly unacceptable to basically rip away unemployment relief from people who are 18 to 20 years of age. I find it strange that we live in a civilised country such as Australia where we can vote at 18 years of age and, if necessary, join the Armed Forces and fight for Australia to defend our strong democratic system, yet at the same time the government suggests that we are dependent on our parents for relief if they earn more than $41,500 as a household, and that therefore it is up to our parents to support us if we are 18 to 20 years of age and unemployed. I think the real problem is that the government does not understand the depth of concern and despair out in the Australian community on the all-important issues of jobs and job security. Speaking about the question of work for the dole, in order to reinforce this issue, I think I should refer in passing to the performance of the new Howard government. I suppose
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Martin Ferguson (Batman) (10.03 A.m.)
theText: In speaking to this particular matter,5904 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 I should emphasise that it is no longer a new government. In fact, it is 15 months old. One would ordinarily suggest that that is probably half the lifetime of a normal parliamentary term. I can already refer today, on a regular basis, to discussions becoming if anything the order of the day from the government about the potential next election and talk of double dissolutions. People are even thinking about the next election, which is an indication that the government is in power, it is considered as the government of the day and the Australian community now expect results rather than rhetoric. The Australian community is getting concerned about the lack of performance of the government, after 15 months, on the question of jobs. They do not see work for the dole as a solution to real jobs for our young unemployed. They are concerned, for example, that the number of jobs has only risen by 86,800 in the first 15 months. Perhaps an even bigger worry to them is the fact that the number of full-time jobs has actually fallen by 700 in this period. The number of male full-time jobs has fallen by 9,900, the number of people unemployed has risen by 39,000, and the unemployment rate has risen from 8.5 to 8.8 per cent. Last but not least, the youth unemployment rate-surprisingly, because the Prime Minister said he would be judged on this issue at the end of his first term-has risen from 27.4 per cent to 27.5 per cent. That takes me to the question of the youth allowance, which is very much an issue for debate out in the public domain at the moment. Not only is it about taking away from young unemployed their entitlement to benefits, but it is also about hiding the unemployed. That is one of the real thrusts about it. They have all of a sudden realised that they are not producing the goods with respect to access to real jobs, so we now have changes to the definition of part-time and full-time work and the introduction of a new youth allowance which is all about hiding-from the Department of Social Security's point of view-the number of young unemployed. It is about time the government faced up to the fact that work for the dole is not a real solution to unemployment. Two days on and five days off does not do a lot for a young person's dignity. What their parents are saying is that they want five days on and two days off. They actually want a definite proposal which requires their young people to front up to a reasonable labour market program with an emphasis on training and a commitment to work; one that really works and achieves the discipline of work. (Time expired) aspects of the 1997-98 budget in the portfolio of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and then discuss in some detail the areas where I do not think this budget goes far enough. The increase in funding for schools is to be commended, as is this government's focus on improving literacy standards for Australian school children. The government's national literacy and numeracy plan is to be commended-my literacy is not too good at the moment, I will stretch my mouth a bit-because getting these basics right is one of the most important roles of our education system. however, whether the emphasis should be on the testing of literacy and numeracy rather than on improved teaching of these skills in the earliest years of schooling. I think that is where the emphasis should be, rather than later when perhaps the opportunity to maximise that training is well and truly lost.
title: Represent Atives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Andren (Calare) (10.08 A.m.)
theText: I will begin with a brief discussion of the positive
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: You are a television journalist, not a print journalist.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Andren
theText: That is right. I have not done my mouth stretching exercises yet. I question,Thursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5905 I am most concerned about the increased emphasis on non-public school funding which threatens to widen the educational gap between the haves and the have-nots. I say that as a parent quite happy to pay $120,000, or thereabouts, after-tax dollars to educate my kids at a non-government school. Maybe 'happy' is not the word; perhaps 'willing' is a better word. I do believe that there is an unfair emphasis on supporting the non-public sector in education, which will prove detrimental to those who do not enjoy the ability or the privilege to educate their kids. We are going to see that percolating up of opportunity, as we have seen with income distribution, to the top 20 per cent of the population, as has been the case in many overseas developed countries, particularly America and other places. We have a working poor and an educationally impoverished section of the community as well. Looking at HECS and Austudy, the more flexible arrangement for the up-front payment of HECS and recognition of the increased cost incurred by rural families in sending their children away to study are both commendable steps in the right direction, though I question whether the Austudy changes go far enough. But I will deal with Austudy a touch later. With regard to apprenticeships and traineeships, the $265 miIIion dedicated to creating 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships is welcome, recognising the needs of young people to make the transition from school to work, as well as upskiIIing the work force in that program. In particular, the establishment of a one-stop apprenticeship and trainee shop, like that presently being set up or trialled in Orange through the efforts and the guidance of Email, is very welcome. It should reduce the complexity of the process for both employers and prospective trainees and apprentices. But we are not generating jobs at the end of the day to soak up those people once they are trained and those privileged enough, the cream, who wilI be able to access those programs. Those who are not the cream of the unemployed wilI certainly stiIl miss out. I am not necessarily supporting the workplace programs, that the former government had because I think that, apart from some like Skillshare, they were too short and they did not offer much long-term hope. I think that we have got to be far more creative in the programs. Work for the dole is only a pittance; it is only a token effort to address the unemployment amongst our youth. I warn of the German experience where a country with the best trained work force in the world has unemployment around 12.75 per cent at last count. There the increasing trend is for trainees and apprentices to join the dole queues once they complete their qualification. It is okay to train our young people, but we also have to create real jobs to meet their understandable expectations of continued employment. Although we have reasonable economic growth and low interest rates at the moment, the job market for young people, especialIy, is extremely tight and, in fact, in regional areas, non-existent for some. All the signs are that it will not improve quickly. I want to go on and comment that community support programs to provide special assistance tailored to the needs of severely disadvantaged job seekers are commendable. (Time expired) dole and, in doing so, indicate that we believe that, unfortunately for the young unemployed in Australia, it is nothing more than poll driven tokenism. In that context I believe that on the issue of jobs, though you would really question the commitment, the government is in panic mode and clutching at straws. I suppose if you were really concerned about the issue of jobs
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Martin Ferguson (Batman) (10.13 A.m.)
theText: I return to the issue of work for the5906 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 at the moment, you would be visiting somewhere, such as Newcastle in New South Wales, rather than Lords to watch the cricket. On the issue of work for the dole, the Premier of Victoria was correct when, on 14 March, he described it in the Melbourne Age in condemning it as 'crazy and irrelevant for the 2 I st century'. It is not often that I identify with the Premier of Victoria. I know that he is a very good friend-if anything, a mate-of the Treasurer, Mr Costello. But I think he understands that if you are really concerned about getting young people back to work, then you have got to be willing to invest in creating opportunities for young people. I must say that the young people I meet with on a regular basis in many regions around Australia raise their concerns, from the department's point of view, about many types of issues. Firstly, they are rather concerned about the fact that this government, through its departmental activities, has actually reduced access to labour market training opportunities. The fact that in its recent budget it did not restore the cuts made to labour market programs that were announced last August represents a huge setback in the minds of those young people and, dare I say, their parents. They then refer to the increasing university fees and the requirement to pay back HECS debts sooner. They take the view that, yes, they are prepared to put their heads down and try their best, but the government should not be putting barriers in the way of creating educational and training opportunities, on the basis of which they desire to pursue real job opportunities. They then referred to the overall lack of a budget strategy and the fact that they would have thought the Treasurer's speech on budget night would have referred to the question of jobs and a jobs target as a number one priority. They said that when they actually read the speech they could only find the question of unemployment mentioned on one occasion. They then raised with me, from the department's point of view, the fact that prior to the budget-in actual fact, in the week prior to the budget-the Reserve Bank governor and the secretary of Treasury had said that, if you really want a capacity to reduce unemployment in Australia, you have to achieve an economic growth rate of four per cent or more. What surprised them was that on budget night they only found a suggested growth rate of the order of 3.75 per cent. So, they really want an explanation from the government. If that is the target or the projection on the question of economic growth, they want an explanation today of where the jobs are going to come from. People at arms-length from the governmentthe Reserve Bank governor and the secretary of Treasury-said that you have to achieve four per cent growth or more actually to reduce the level of unemployment. I think it is important today that the ministerial secretary actually outlines where those jobs are going to come from and how a projected growth rate of 3.75 per cent, which is less than that suggested to reduce unemployment by the Reserve Bank and the Treasury, will actually produce the jobs. It is also important to start to identify the regions and the industries in which those jobs are going to come. I raise that because we have finally realised to some extent that, as the Australian said on 14 June, there is a real jobs crisis. Its headline on the first page was 'Jobs crisis knocks out another 40,300'. I know we had the 43-bean explanation from the minister on that day-as Mike Gordon, writing in the Australian, referred to-but I do not know how 43 beans equate to 40,300 additional unemployed in one month. This is what worries young people: the fact that 40,300 disappeared in one month. That is the most recent outcome of the performance of this government on the question of jobs. That is why they ask how it can be said that work Thursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5907 for the dole is going to lead to real jobs, when they see more than 40,000 jobs disappear in one month. What worries them even more is that, of those 40,000 plus jobs, 23,000 jobs-not an insignificant figure for one month-were full-time jobs, and yet the government says that it is making progress on the question of reducing unemployment. When you go to the question of the overall budget strategy-and that is why I raise this matter today-there are now 57,400 fewer full-time jobs in Australia. (Time expired) reduction in funding for labour market programs, and I want to expand on my concerns about the high unemployment that we have in this country. High unemployment, of course, is creating a feeling of insecurity in those people who are unemployed and also in people who are currently in jobs, who want to know how long they will remain in employment. This lack of confidence simply means that the Australian people do not believe that the government, which has now been in power for 15 months, has the answers to our country's economic problems. I believe the government has wasted a golden opportunity. It won the 1996 election by a large majority, and all new governments, irrespective of their majority or their political persuasion, enjoy a honeymoon period in which the people who have elected them are prepared to give them a go. However, I believe that this government has lost the opportunity to build confidence in the community. They have failed. I believe the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) lives in the past and that he has no answers for the problems of the future. After being in power for some 15 months, the government now has a policy vacuum in the area of employment. Of course, this policy vacuum is being filled by simple solution theories, as advocated by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). I refer to the headline that appeared in the Australian yesterday and which emphasised the lack of confidence that is out there. It read, 'Double blow dashes job hopes'. I will quote a couple of extracts from that article. It begins: Long-term unemployment has leapt 16 per cent over the past 12 months and the jobless rate rose to twice the national average in some blackspots, highlighting the jobs crisis facing the community and the Howard government. A further quote says that the opposition spokesman for employment, Martin Ferguson, has said: ... the trend number of long-term jobseekers-the figure calculated by smoothing out the monthly fluctuations-had reached its highest level in two years. Also in trend terms, the number of long-term unemployed has risen steadily to account for 30 per cent of the total number out of work. The article finishes up by saying: In Newcastle and the Hunter region-where the impending closure of BHP's steelmaking operations will see around 2500 jobs lost by 1999-the jobless rate was 11-12 per cent last month, representing 27,400 people out of work. The other point that I would like to make while speaking on this issue is that the new British government does seem to have some answers to this problem. Their answers are very similar to what the Australian Labor party is suggesting on this occasion. IfI could read another extract from the Australian of 18 June: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, has said the key aims of New Labour's employment strategy are to give young and long-term unemployed people new opportunities, help single parents back to work and provide lifelong educational opportunities to help everyone to acquire new skills. Mr Brown promised 250,000 young unemployed people subsidised jobs through a tax rebate of 60 ($135)
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Mossfield (Greenway) (10.18 A.m.)
theText: I once again express my concern about the5908 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 a week to employers, involving either a community and voluntary organisation program, or a new environment taskforce. Each of these options for work will offer day-release education or training leading to a qualification. Britain's long-term unemployed-those out of work for two years or more-will be subsidised into work through a 7S a week rebate for employers. This will create real jobs with real employers, not make-believe jobs run by some well meaning charitable organisations or community groups. These are real jobs with real employers. The other point is that the emphasis in the UK is quite clearly on training. That is not here in the current government's work for the dole program. The day-release education, as advocated in the UK example, but also the training-(Time expired) everybody is missing the point in this debate. While the former government, the current government and governments all around the world are thrashing around for an answer to the unemployment situation, we just have to realise that downsizing, rationalisation, privatisation, technology replacing jobs and the fact that there are no manual jobs out there any more means that we have to find a new definition for work. We have to find what meaningful occupations we can put a lot of these people into in the years ahead because we just cannot provide employment in the traditional sense. We keep bashing our heads against the wall accusing each other of lacking any sort of vision in this area. We have to sit down and work out how we are going to soak up these people and whether we can work out jobs programs that are meaningful. They will be part-time. They might be two days a week ad infinitum. They might be grafted onto other public programs, but we cannot look at the traditional way of providing jobs as we have done in the past. I will reserve judgment on the government's radical changes to the provision of employment services through the PEPEs and so on. I am sceptical of how the new competitive arrangements will work in regional areas like mine where there are only limited employers looking for young people and where I do not envisage there will be the same level of competition as in the nonrural electorates. As well, this market-driven system will mean that the brokers will target only the cream of the unemployed for their programs, for only they will deliver the bounty on offer at the end of the day. Of course, with the new youth allowance, families with 16and 17-year-old kids cannot afford to keep them. They too will miss out on these training opportunities. Believe me, they will be out on the streets in regional towns and we will have an increase in delinquency. There could also-and I would hate to support the comment necessarily that Senator Kernot made-be more youth suicides because of this hopelessness that is out there. I know members of the coalition are concerned about this aspect of the youth allowance. I would ask the government to have a good, hard look at it again because it is going to leave many youths outside the safety net. We cannot just graft our youth back onto the family. It is simplistic nonsense to talk about this wonderful family concept as the answer. It is not the answer. We have dysfunctional families out there and we have got to take cognisance of that fact. Concerning Austudy, to gauge the nature of public sentiment regarding the operation of AustudyI will quote some constituent letters which the parliamentary secretary should be interested in. This one says: Austudy is a nightmare. You need an accountant to fill it in, but if you can't afford one of these you are penalised because you put the wrong answers in the wrong boxes.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Andren (Calare) (10.23 A.m.)
theText: Concerning the jobs for the dole issue, I thinkThursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5909 Another says: Just from my own experience, the emotional and financial strain that has been placed on our family makes you realise the enormous amount people have suffered. Another says: I fail to see how a family who qualifies for a low income rebate on tax does not qualify for Austudy. Do any of you live hand to mouth by day? Try it. You are institutionalising a system which will leave people no other option than to try to cheat it. That says it all, and to think that this same test will now be applied across the board in the youth allowance. This test is going to occur despite rulings by at least one member of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal stating that the test is doomed to failure unless its whole structure is changed. The test is far too complicated for the average person to comprehend. The reliance on estimates of future expenditure is ridiculous. It does not allow for the fluctuating nature of income derived from many rural farms and small businesses. The benchmark in many cases does not line up fairly with PAYE equivalent incomes. The phone service is inadequate, and while I am sure it has caught some of the smarties that it was meant to, the evidence I have seen-and we have done heaps of surveys in my electorate conducted by my youth officer who has put so much time and effort into this-is that in some cases it has also discriminated against the very people it was designed to protect. Finally, the government, in its desperation to cut funding outlays, has severely hurt Charles Sturt University in my electorate, and others, with cuts to the Commonwealth industry placement scheme. We all know what the Wood royal commission found about police training and so on. Charles Sturt has 3,000 students. It has lost $10 million in support. It must be restored, not patched up as the government is trying to do with it, it must be restored because this is the sort of study that Charles Sturt is now involved in that is vital to the community. (Time expired) by the member for Calare( Mr Andren). I think there is a capacity to create jobs, and I am talking about real full-time jobs. It is not to suggest that we should not be proud of our record, irrespective of who is in government, on the creation of part-time jobs because part-time jobs suit the circumstances of some households and individuals or family units. However, it really comes back to the overall budget strategy and your capacity to create real jobs. By way of comparison I want to refer to this government's performance in its first 15 months compared to the performance of the Hawke Labor government in its first 15 months. I indicate for the record that in the Labor government's first 15 months, after March 1983, we cut the legacy of 10 per cent unemployment left to us by the then Treasurer and current Prime Minister, Mr Howard, to 8.9 per cent. As the Prime Minister said on the 7.30 Report last Thursday, he has been left with a big ship to tum around on the unemployment front. He appealed for patience and understanding. We also had a big ship to tum around in 1983 in our first 15 months because there was double digit unemployment. We made inroads into unemployment, we reduced it to 8.9 per cent in that first 15 months because we had a strategy that was about economic growth and the creation of jobs. Strangely, in the first 15 months of this government, not only has youth unemployment not fallen, unemployment itself has risen from 8.5 to 8.8 per cent.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Martin Ferguson (Batman) (10.28 A.m.)
theText: I want to pick up on an issue raised5910 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 i take the view that what we want to see from the department-and unfortunately I question the current budget strategy-is an overall strategy that has a focus on decent labour market programs and the creation of local infrastructure opportunities that can gainfully employ people, especially some of the long-term unemployed, but also goes to the question of economic growth. I refer to the fact that we are concerned-and we are looking for the ministerial secretary or apprentice minister's explanation today-as to how an expected growth rate of 3.75 per cent is actually going to produce those jobs. I hope to see him as the minister one day. I understand he has his eyes on the job of the Minister for Schools and Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp), but he wants to be in cabinet, unlike the minister. I go to the need to actually restore expenditure on labour market programs but, perhaps more importantly, I also want to deal with the question of the fall-off in growth in apprenticeships and traineeships. At Senate estimates last week it was confirmed that there has been a fall of about 1,000 apprenticeships in the last year. That is despite all the hype about the new modem Australian apprenticeship scheme. I also found it surprising that the growth in traineeships has fallen from 117 per cent in Labor's last year to just 32 per cent in the first 12 months of the Howard government. I suppose that really goes to the question of whether or not you are prepared to restore expenditure on funding for apprenticeships. In a recent press release titled 'Funding for new apprenticeships' the Minister for Schools and Vocational Education and Training sought to portray the government as providing $265 million for 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships in 1997-98. That is grossly misleading, but I understand that, from time to time, the minister likes to fudge the figures. He has a record for that. He was well known for doing that in some of his academic writings prior to coming into the parliament. to that very issue. I think you will find them interesting, from a ministerial secretary's point of view. I found them interesting. On the question of funding for vocational education and training, the real facts are that funding has been cut, not increased: $14.3 million will be cut from vocational education and training and $72 million will be cut from vocational education and training grants to the states, to add to the $183 million cut in last year's budget. It is a real problem that the number of apprenticeships fell in 1996-97, despite the government's so called publicity about MAA TS and new apprenticeships, and the growth in traineeships fell from that achieved in the last 12 months of the Labor Party compared to the first 12 months of the Howard government. It comes back to opportunities and whether or not you are prepared to invest in those opportunities. (Time expired) I want to say something about the work for the dole program. I would like to put it in the context that certainly we cannot say that it will not do any good-it may well do some good in some areas-but we believe it is a second-rate program. I believe it is a lazy program where very little thought was put into constructing it in the first place. One of the really great concerns I have about the work for the dole program is that it does not contain any provision for training, nor does it contain any provision for recognition of the skills that may be obtained during the short period of time that these people will be in employment. A number of people have looked at this particular problem, in particular, Richard Sweet from the Dusseldorf Foundation, who recognises that the people who work for the dole will be
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: That is a bit tough.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Martin Ferguson
theText: If you want, I will give you a few articles to read with respect
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Mossfield (Greenway) (L0.33 A.m.)
theText: In continuing my contribution in this debate,Thursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5911 people on the fringe of the labour market who, for some period of time, may not actually get into full-time employment. These people may well work for a month or a shorter period of time, they may move on to another job or may be unemployed for a while. They may then get into employment but in a different area to where they were before. But as they move through this range of part-time work, they are not acquiring any recognition of the skills that they will probably attain during this period of employment. This is a great weakness in this program. I appeal to the government to look very closely at recognising the skills that people acquire during this period of training. They should be certified so that, as they move through their working life, they can take these qualifications with them. They should have a certificate which says that they have worked for X period of time in this particular type of work and that they acquired certain skills while doing it. If that weakness in the program is rectified, the unemployed people who go into this program will benefit greatly. I have concerns about other areas of the work for the dole program. It appears to me that the government is taking a fairly pessimistic view of employment growth. I do not think it would have introduced this type of program if it felt that unemployment levels were going to drop. I believe that the government does not have any programs or plans to overcome unemployment. It appears that this scheme was introduced very hastily. It was introduced by the minister through a very short statement. There were many other problems confronting the government at the time. People could be excused for saying that this was a smokescreen to take attention away from some of the government's other problems. Coming from a trade union background, I am concerned about the people who work for the dole. This program will be award free. Their rights will not be protected while they are working. They will not come under the recognised workers compensation provisions, although I understand that there may be some insurance that will protect them if they are injured. Members on this side of the House are concerned that people who work for the dole will not be covered by an appropriate industrial award. Once again, this contrasts very distinctly with the programs of the previous Labor government. People who worked in labour market programs were covered by an appropriate industrial award. I believe this is an attack on the awards system that has protected working class people in this country for many years. Quite clearly, this government is trying to weaken the trade union movement and it is trying to weaken award coverage. Whether it is intended or not in the work for the dole proposal, this is certainly what is happening. Interestingly, many employer organisations are saying that this program will not make people job ready. For a start, it is for a short period of time-only two days a week-and so people will not be conditioned to arrive at work on time, do a good day's work, go home and then come back the next day, and do that on a continuing basis. If people who have been out of work for a period of -ime are going to get job ready, they need to have continuation of employment. They do not need spasmodic periods, where they work for two days one week and two days the next. I believe that the government is considering the possibility of bringing that all together so that people will work for a full week or for a fortnight, and then maybe have a period of time off. (Time expired) unemployment. I remind the chamber that Mr Howard said that youth unemployment was the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Martin Ferguson (Batman) (10.38 A.m.)
theText: I return to the issue of youth5912 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 biggest social problem facing Australia. He went into the election campaign committing himself to doing big things for the young unemployed of Australia. I touch on the question of work for the dole, which will apply, for example, to 18to 20year-olds. I have a question for the government: if I am a 19-year-old and, on the basis of the announcement going to the issue of youth allowance, based on my parents' household income I am not entitled to unemployment benefits, is there a guarantee that, if I am required to work on a compulsory basis, as suggested by the government, will I receive a payment for that compulsory requirement to participate in the work for the dole program? I also raise what I find a strange proposition. I refer in passing to the Green Corps. The Green Corps is very small when compared with the old LEAP program. The majority of participants in Green Corps to date have actually had jobs or been in full-time education. I find it strange that at the end of their program they are entitled to an additional allowance of $500 to go on to a further training opportunity. Why isn't a similar allowance available, for example, to people who will be compulsorily required to work for the dole? Work for the dole is not going to go to some people who have been fortunate enough in the past to have had jobs or been engaged in full-time training or education opportunities. Surely those participants should be encouraged at the end of a compulsory requirement to undertake work for the dole to a grant of, say, $500-similar to Green Corps-to go on to a training opportunity. I say that because, whilst I have serious problems with the question of work for the dole, the value of some of the labour market programs such as LEAP was that that actually gave the young person the opportunity to work themselves out from a personal point of view and to come to terms with their lack of discipline in work and some of the personal difficulties that they had. The time was used by them to actually work out what they wanted to do in the future, such as a traineeship or an apprenticeship. In that context, it is very valuable that they be given some additional assistance or encouragement to go on and take up an alternative training opportunity. We are putting aside the question of the value or otherwise of work for the dole and raising what we should be doing for those people who are going to have the stigma of saying to an employer, 'Yes, I am a graduate of work for the dole; two days on, five days off. But would you please put that aside because I really want to do something with my life.' The explanation I am looking for from the government is of when we will get some additional encouragement for those people to actually get some financial assistance to go on to alternative training opportunities. I say that because I think youth unemployment is a major problem. I am vitally concerned with the fact that, after 15 months of this government, not only have they not made a dent in youth unemployment, but youth unemployment has risen in Australia. More importantly, we are getting suburbs and regions of very high youth unemployment. In fact, the national capital, that the Prime Minister has turned his back on as not being good enough as the centre of government any more, is an area of high youth unemployment. Those people out there in the suburbs of Canberra are looking for more than work for the dole and a Green Corps program that largely benefits people in terms of full-time jobs or training opportunities. I say in conclusion that we have got major concerns with the performance of this department but not in isolation. It goes to the whole budget strategy of this government. Unless we get a higher level of economic growth we are not going to make a huge impact on reducing unemployment in Australia. The truth of the matter is that the reduction in interest rates to Thursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 5913 date, and there have been four reductions, are not a vote of confidence with respect to the performance of this government. I suppose the Reserve Bank is doing what this government has failed to do. They are trying to stimulate some investment and encouragement out there. They have finally realised that they should not just be concerned about building on our achievements from the point of view of breaking the back of inflation. They have come to terms with the fact that the Treasurer is wrong to focus just on the question of the rate of inflation and they must be vitally concerned with the issue of unemployment. We have an alltime high. We have also a deterioration I might say in terms of long-term unemployment. We need a regional strategy to help those people. (Time expired) Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (10.39 a.m.)-I would like to thank all members who participated in the debate this morning because I think that it has been more constructive than these debates sometimes are. Perhaps this is the nature of the committee stage of debate. I do have a few comments to make. Naturally, all members on this side of the House share the concern of all members on that side of the House about the unemployment problem. It is, as the Prime Minister( Mr Howard) has frequently said both before and after the election, the most serious problem that Australia faces. I am prepared to attribute good faith to members opposite and I hope members opposite are prepared to attribute good faith to members of the government on this subject. Naturally, as a member of the government I am concerned that after 15 months the unemployment problem is not appreciably better than it was at the time of the election. I am concerned, as members opposite are concerned-we are all concerned. The Prime Minister is concerned. One of the reasons the Prime Minister is in England is to talk to the British Prime Minister and then later when he goes to America to the American President about their options for tackling this very problem. One thing does slightly disappoint me about members opposite. They are quite properly drawing attention to the fact that after 15 months of this government the situation is not markedly different, at least in terms of the statistics, but after 13 years of their government, where were we at? In the 13 years of the recent Labor government, unemployment never dropped below six per cent and averaged over eight per cent. Their government presided over a great deal of restructuring in the private sector and public sector, all of which resulted in job losses. Full-time jobs only rose by 7,000 between 1991 and 1996, at the same time as the former government ran up government debt of $75 billion. WhatI would like from members opposite is a little bit more fair-mindedness and appreciation that the level of unemployment is a difficulty, tragedy and disaster that many governments in many countries are grappling with. There are no magic wands, there are no quick fixes. If there were magic wands and quick fixes, does anyone think that they wouldn't have been applied long before now? Briefly, the government's strategy to reduce unemployment has four basic elements. First of all, we want to make the overall economy more buoyant and the very considerable interest rate reductions that we have seen are at the heart of that strategy. Surely we should get some credit at least for putting in place fiscal conditions that made it easier for the Reserve Bank to allow those reductions. Labour market flexibility is very important. I want to stress that this government is not about reducing wages, this government is about increasing wages. What we want to see is the ability
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Abbott (Warringah
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment,5914 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 of workers to work more productively and the ability of workers and managers to work productively together so that businesses are more productive. Better training and better education are a very important part of the government's strategy. I will touch on that in a few moments when I respond to some of the comments of the member for Batman( Mr Martin Ferguson) about apprenticeships. Finally, there are some important structural changes that we are putting in place. Work for the dole is an important structural change because we are trying to establish the principle that people ought to be prepared to give something back in return for the support that society gives them. I appreciate the comments of members opposite that the work for the dole scheme does not involve anything like the formal training that many of the former government's labour market programs involved. But the fact is that members opposite did not oppose the work for the dole scheme when it went through the House. I really think that great indignation from them is slightly phoney, given that they did not oppose it when it went through the House. The youth allowance changes are also a very important part of changing the culture of this nation. What we are saying with our changes to the benefit situation for people aged 16 to 18 is that they really should be in education or training. (Time expired) raised by the ministerial secretary. In passing, I might refer to the Reuter's poll of this week. It touches on the question of interest rates and suggests there is about a 60 per cent view that there will be a further half per cent reduction in interest rates. It really relates to whether or not it represents confidence in the government's strategy to date, because this is what this poll says. Thursday's May labour force data shocked the economic forecasting community. The typical economist now sees a 60 per cent probability of the Reserve Bank effecting another interest rate cut, compared to 35 per cent a couple of weeks ago. That really is made in the context of the unemployment problem that this government has created. I was also looking for an explanation from the government about whether or not the department was really comprehensively consulted by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs on the recent announcement going to the immigration intake. What surprises and concerns me is that at a time when the government is trying to argue to the Australian community that it has reduced the migration intake because of the high level of unemployment, in its first 15 months it has in fact increased independent skilled migration by 50 per cent. As we all appreciate, that independent skilled migration group is the untargeted and not matched group with skills and labour market shortages. I raise that because at the same time the government has slashed $269 million from vocational and industry training programs and more than $2 billion out of jobs programs. I really think it is important that there are ongoing and regular discussions between this department and the department of immigration on matching the skilled requirements of this great nation and the migration intake. What concerns me is that at the time that we have increased the independent skilled migration, the untargeted and not matched program, by 50 per cent, we have got a cut in government employment in these first two budgets of 28,000 jobs, many of which are in regional Australia. There are 8,000 Defence jobs to go. I suggest that jobs will also go as a result of the program of competitive tendering of information
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Martin Ferguson (Batman) (10.49 A.m.)
theText: I want to take up a couple of questionsThursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5915 technology. There are 700 meat inspectors jobs to go as a result of the AQIS decisions of this budget. Then we have potential job losses of 12,000 as a result of changes to pharmaceuticals. This is an important process currently under way in this chamber. It is important that we raise questions and queries with a view to trying to get a better understanding of the issues and also to make suggestions about how current programs can be improved. That is why I raised the question of whether, in considering work for the dole-and we moved a series of amendments to improve it, which is not acknowledged by the government today, because we seriously questioned the value of that proposal-another proposal could be considered for a training grant of $500 at the end of work for the dole, similar to that received by people who participate and graduate from the Green Corps. When you are out there arguing that and, considering the issue of unemployment, that you also base your immigration intake on that now, what comprehensive discussions did or did not occur and what were the issues that were put forward by this department with respect to influencing the government's decision on immigration and the argument that it has been reduced because of the high level of unemployment and the deterioration in employment in Australia as a result of the first 15 months of this government's performance? That is vitally important, because from a bottom line point of view the real problem is that the budget hardly talks about the issue of jobs. It is mentioned once in the speech by the Treasurer ( Mr Costello). There is no real job target, as ACCI suggested this week, of six per cent. All the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) can talk about is a cup of Nescafe and being patient. The 43-bean solution is inadequate. People are concerned about the loss of 40,300 jobs in one month. We want explanations, not pie in the sky statements that the government is concerned about unemployment, at the same time that it says that people ought to be patient and that 18to 20-year-olds should no longer be entitled to unemployment relief if their parents have a household income of $41,500. I would like to see the apprentice minister ring up kids, including kids who are 18 to 20 years of age, and deny them unemployment relief, because I tell you what, he would have a few troubles at home. It is hard enough to negotiate with your kids about pocket money at the moment, let alone saying to l8-to 20-year-olds that they are not entitled to unemployment relief because mum and dad have to bring up a couple more kids. (Time expired) Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (10.53 a.m.)-People were very patient for 13 years with the former government. Believe me, if we have that length of time and if we have the same results, we will certainly deserve to be expelled from government. To get back to the youth allowance proposal, we are saying that 16to 18-year-olds, unless there are some extraordinary circumstances, should be in full-time education or training. The problem with the former government's policy was that it had young Australians sitting in the pinball parlours and the video parlours of our inner cities. I do not pretend for a moment that that is what members opposite intended, but that was what their policy allowed and that is what our policy is going to prevent. The other problem with the former government's policy was that the former government's policy gave people an economic incentive to go out of education and onto unemployment benefits. By equalising the conditions under which people get this allowance, we are ensuring that there is no disincentive to study. Surely that is a good thing. It is a good thing that there
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Abbott (Warringah
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment,5916 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 is no disincentive for people to get out of education and get onto the dole. Encouraging people, young people especially, to be on the dole is simply not on, and that is why this government has made these important changes. I am attempting to answer the points made by the honourable member for Batman( Mr Martin Ferguson)debate, they can do so after the parliamentary secretary finishes. Please do not interrupt when he is speaking. If you want to have five minutes, save it, and come in later. The parliamentary secretary will be heard in silence. member for Batman raised was the Green Corps. He made the observation that only 50 per cent, or thereabouts, of the Green Corps participants so far were formerly unemployed, and that is true. I do not regard that as a problem because there is a difference between the Green Corps and labour market programs. Green Corps is not a labour market program; Green Corps is a youth environmental program. He is really, I think, comparing an apple with an orange. Green Corps is a different program, and I have got to say that it is an excellent program. So far, people who have been involved with the Green Corps and were previously involved with program such as LEAP, believe that Green Corps has taken the LEAP experience and built on it to produce a much better program. The whole point about Green Corps is that everyone who is in a Green Corps team is a volunteer, whereas, the people who were in LEAP were essentially conscripts, and that has produced a very different temper and ethos amongst the participants. The honourable member for Batman wanted to know about consultation between the immigration department and the department of employment over changes to the skilled migration rate. As far as I am aware, the normal consultations that go on between departments on these matters did go on. I do not see that there is a problem with bringing people into this country as independent skilled migrants because the fact is they are supposed to come in under that category only if there is work for them. Obviously, if there is work for people, there is no reason that they should not be brought in. In concluding these comments prompted by the contribution of the honourable member of Batman, let me just say again that I think there is a real problem today when we have members opposite running around increasing the gloom and despair felt by some people in Australia. These are difficult times for many Australians. No-one pretends otherwise. We have not entered an economic nirvana, just as we were not in an economic nirvana for the 13 years of the former government. But the fact is that every time we have outrageous and patently ridiculous statements from people like the honourable member for Banks( Mr Melham), it makes the problem worse. If their feeling for Australia was practical as well as theoretical, their contribution would be a lot more constructive than the sort of loud-mouthed effort that we have got from them today. (Time expired) attempting to interject, should remain silent. He should participate in the spirit of this chamber which is not shouting across the chamber. of the parliamentary secretary in relation to two matters that he has spoken about. The first point is about school participation. The suggestion that has been put forward by this
