title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Kerr (Denison) (10.59 A.m.)
theText: I think that I should take up the obvious self-deceptionThursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITIEE 5917 government is that it has some form of policy mortgage on the idea that young Australians should seek to better their educational opportunities rather than to be placed on unemployment benefits. The reality is that the period when Australia saw the greatest growth in participation at secondary and tertiary education was during the last 13 years of a Labor government. Before that period, participation rates nationally were below any international comparisons. We had literally thousands of our best and brightest people unable to go past year 10 in their educationthem to go on into higher education, into post-secondary education through the technical and further education system and the universities. What the former government did was to radically transform the pattern of youth education in this country. A great majority of young people now complete year 12 education, and the participation levels through tertiary and post-secondary education have massively increased. But there will still be those who complete their education at year 10. There is no way that this nation is going to have a system whereby all Australians will benefit from participating in education past year 10. That is the reality. A failure to provide any employment opportunities for those people is the charge we sheet home to this government. In the past, when it was in opposition, the government criticised us for putting in place labour market programs which had a significant training component, saying that that was shifting people from the unemployment market and into 'mickey mouse' schemes, as it described them, in order to take them out of the unemployment statistics. But those so-called mickey mouse schemes all had elements of training to increase people's employability and job readiness. What this government is now doing is putting in place an economic regime that simply says, 'We will park you in the education system which is already bursting at the seams, notwithstanding that there is no discernible benefit that you will achieve and that there is certainly a disbenefit to the overall participation rates of those who would go on into tertiary and secondary education, because they could have got some benefit from it. We will park in the system all you people for whom that system will contribute no benefit at all, and that is the only way that you are going to receive any support from this government.' To the extent that they shift people who are genuinely seeking employment across from the job search task into fruitless educational endeavour, they will take people off the unemployment lists. This is a way of disguising long-term and short-term unemployment amongst Australia's youth. For an opposition that had said that national unemployment amongst youth was a disgrace, what they are doing now in government is avoiding any responsibility whatsoever. What are they going to say? My colleague the member for Franklin( Mr Quick) made the point that, in Tasmania, there are going to be some 700 people who will now go into the already bulging high schools, in circumstances where there is nothing to give them any net advantage-simply because that will be their only way of gaining any income support. This is an outrageous and wrong approach. The other point I would make about the independent category in migration is that Parliamentary Secretary Abbott simply misunderstands. There is no requirement for an independent applicant to demonstrate any employment need in this country whatsoever. The rest of the labour market programs require that; and what we have said is that the independent
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Melham
theText: The rates were below 30 per cent.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Kerr
theText: They were below 30 per cent. Thousands were without a framework to enable5918 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 category should be scrapped and that all skilled migration should be linked to labour market needs in this country. (Time expired) has been spoken by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs( Mr Abbott), because the facts speak for themselves. The former Labor government had a proud history over 13 years. The retention rate in schools doubled from over 30 per cent to over 70 per cent by the time our period in government was finished. The former Whitlam government's performance in higher education, in creating opportunities for those who did not have the money, was second to none. That is why I joined the Labor Party. I was one of 10 children. I got my university education, courtesy of the vision of the Whitlam Labor government, which opened up the universities. It is the role of government to create opportunities. What we have seen in just over 13 months of this government is that this is a government for the rich. It is not about creating opportunities. This is a government that leaves people to their own devices and says, 'Oh, governments should not be involved in the marketplace,' but then it imposes its morality on the public. That is what you have got in store for the 16to 18-year olds. That is your view of the family-your view of the path that they should take. The previous Labor government was a government that did not divide the communities, that had a safety net. Thatcher and Major were subsequently rejected in Great Britain. At a time when Mother England has rejected the Tories, the colonies have embraced them. At a time when America has rejected Reagan and Bush, poor old Australia has embraced the Tories. Why? Because after 13 years, they forgot what it was like to be under a Tory government. But we know what a Howard government will be like. What was John Howard's record in his period in the Fraser government as Treasurer in relation to this area? In relation to unemployment, it left us with unemployment at over 10 per cent. That is what we were left with. Our period in government created opportunities in a changing work force in a changing society. The problem with your Prime Minister and your government is that you hark back to the old days. That is what we find offensive about this budget and these proposals. The old days have gone forever. You are not going to make people 'comfortable and relaxed' in relation to this budget and what you have brought down. What you have done is betray the young people, on whose misery you piggybacked into government, offering them hope. That is what this part of the budget is. It is a betrayal of what you promised these people. You will be judged on your record. After just over 13 months, you do not deserve re-election. This is a policy that is backward looking, that is insular looking and one that does not recognise the changes in our society that have occurred. The Lyons Forum is controlling this government. Your former adviser, where is he? The one who made the changes to Abstudy, where is he? You picked up his changes. He drafted your policy on Abstudy and what did you do? You picked it up and ran with it and where is he now? On the staff of the member for Oxley( Mrs Hanson). You criticise the member for Oxley, but what you do is ride on her coat-tails. She is your creation. She is your leader's creation. The policies that you implement in this area are policies that she would embrace and endorse. It is a backward looking government and the people will finally and eventually wake up to you. In the end, what you preach is not what is going to happen out there in the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Melham (Banks) (11.04 A.m.)
theText: I am encouraged into this debate by the rubbish thatThursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5919 community. This policy will result in greater misery, in greater suffering and in greater pressure on the youth and families of this country. People are leaving the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs because they believed in a lot of the policies and the vision of what was happening. You have destroyed that vision. You are gutting the department. Decent people are leaving and you are losing the corporate memory. You are now getting a government of the lowest common denominator. That is what these policies are about. You cater to the low performers and to the rednecks in the community. (Time expired) . by the parliamentary secretary in his reference to the importance of Green Corps and the fact that it is a voluntary scheme for those who have got jobs or an education. I think the real problem is that he does not understand at the moment the biggest problem the Australian community confronts is the issue of getting jobs for those who are unemployed and those who lack a sense of job security in their lives. Green Corps might be all right in a time of high unemployment. The issue today is getting jobs for the unemployed. The issue today is not taking unemployment benefits off 18to 20year-olds; it is actually creating real jobs. He says, 'Yes, they are volunteers.' It is strange that you reward volunteers with a training levy of $500 but you say to the unemployed, especially the long-term unemployed, that all we can offer for you is work for the dole. Some of us cut our teeth opposing the coalition government's approach to compulsion with respect to conscription in Vietnam. We were not going to be thrown in as cannon fodder for Vietnam, nor are we going to accept in this day and age that young unemployed people ought to cop the stigma of work for the dole with no hope at the end of that compulsory program. Those programs that we pursued, such as LEAP, were especially important for regional Australia. I think the parliamentary secretary owes this chamber an explanation as to why unemployment in 77 per cent of rural and regional Australia is worse off as a result of the performance of this government in its first 12 months. Those communities embraced and supported decent labour market programs, such as New Work Opportunities and LEAP, but I suppose he needs to be reminded how desperate it is out there. He ought to start talking to his coalition mates in the Northern Rivers of New South Wales, the people who cover the areas of Lismore, Coffs Harbour, Taree, Tweed Heads, Grafton and Port Macquarie, because unemployment in that region this week is 14.5 per cent. The national average is 8.8 per cent, and the government says, 'Be patient.' In the Northern Rivers region there are now 3,000 more unemployed people. speech of the member for Batman but the member for Banks is persistently attempting to interject and standing order 55 does require that members be heard in silence. I suggest that, if the member for Banks is unable to control himself, he should be asked to leave the chamber. member for Banks his conduct in this chamber. I would ask him to enter into the spirit of the chamber and not interject. As I said, there is the ability to participate in the debate. If he feels strongly about an issue, when the member for Batman or, indeed, the parliamentary secretary finishes, he can always stand and give the whole chamber the benefit of a five-minute speech instead of a quick interjection.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Martin Ferguson (Batman) (11.09 A.m.)
theText: I want to take up an issue referred to
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Abbou

title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Hollis)
theText: I have constantly drawn to the attention of the5920 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 debate, despite the rude interruption by the parliamentary secretary. As I was saying, in the Northern Rivers of New South Wales there are 3,000 more unemployed people today than in March 1996. SoI understand why there was that rude interruption by the parliamentary secretary when I was referring to these vital figures. Let us go to the black spots of Victoria; the government likes to talk about black spots. Rural and regional unemployment in Victoria is now at 11.2 per cent. 'Be patient: have a cup of Nescafe.' That is the minister's view about the issue of unemployment today. Let us go to the Gippsland region. We know the minister does not like to spend a lot of time in Gippsland; he finds it more attractive to stay in East Melbourne. What is the unemployment rate in the Gippsland region? It is 12.9 per cent compared to March 1996 when it was 9.2 per cent. IfI were him I would find East Melbourne more attractive too, rather than being accountable for the deterioration in employment. Now let us go to the central highlands and the Wimmera. The unemployment rate there is 9.8 per cent compared to 7.9 per cent in March of 1996. In the Barwon and western district region-Gee long, Hamilton and Portland-it is 12.9 per cent compared to 8.4 per cent in March of 1996. I think the parliamentary secretary owes this chamber an explanation. Why have we got higher regional unemployment? (Time expired) Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (11.14 a.m.)-I do intend to try to give explanations to as much as is capable of explanation in the various accusations and interjections from those members opposite. One important issue that the member for Batman( Mr Martin Ferguson) raised earlier was this whole question of apprenticeships and traineeships. I am advised by the department that apprentice and trainee commencements were 67,900 in 1994-95,85,100 in 1995-96 and are estimated to have been 94,500 in 1996-97. I should also draw to the attention of the member for Batman the advice I have received from the department that in this government's budgets for 1996-97 and 1997-98 Commonwealth funding for vocational education and training totals $1.354 billion, compared with an expenditure of only $1.2 billion when the Labor Party was in government. These figures, I am advised, show that the government has increased its allocation on vocational education and training by $144 million, or almost 12 per cent. I now wish to return to some of the more general comments that the member for Batman and other members opposite have made. As I have said, there is no easy answer to the unemployment problem. The socialistic answers of the 1970s failed. The ultra-market solutions that were tried by the former government in the 1980s were disappointingly slow to work. Obviously, what the new government is moving towards is, if you like, a new paradigm which builds on the strengths of the market but which does not expect it to do everything. The question that I really should pose to the member for Batman and other members opposite is: what is the Labor Party's answer to these problems? Over 13 years, as I said, unemployment averaged over eight per cent. So, plainly, the answers opposite were not so brilliant. The member for Batman seems to be suggesting that we should resurrect Working Nation, with all its $2 billion a year expense. Is the shadow Treasurer ( Mr Gareth Evans) going to provide the member for Batman with $2 billion? Can the member for Batman guarantee that should he be whisked magically onto the government benches, that he would have an extra $2 billion to spend on this? Is that the kind of guarantee that the member for Batman can give,
title: Representatives Main Committee

theText: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate returning to the

speaker: Mr Abbott (Warringah
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment,Thursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5921 because if he cannot give that guarantee, he is exposed as a phoney, as someone who waxes self-righteous in opposition but does nothing in government. What are the answers that the member for Batman has? So far, the only answer that the member for Batman has come up with is the idea of job sharing. Job sharing was described as a ludicrous and nonsensical solution by his colleague-and, I dare say friend, the member for Melbourne ( Mr Tanner), his rival for the leadership of the national left faction. So plainly there are just no answers on the other side of the House. Mr Martin Ferguson-I am on the national left, am I? contribution of the member for Banks( Mr Melham). He accused the government of going back to the old days. Of course, it was the member for Melbourne who accused many members opposite of wanting to go waltzing down memory lane, hand in hand with Pauline Hanson. It was the member for Banks who talked about the former government bringing the nation together and not dividing communities. Even the member for Banks surely must find the great healing figure, slightly ludicrous. Let us face it, the former Prime Minister was the man who regularly denounced people in this very building as unrepresentative swill, and so on. than can be said formember for Banks and I will continue these comments in a moment. In particular, I want to comment on his remark that the policy that the government has adopted on Abstudy is in some way the creation of my former adviser. My former adviser had no policy role whatsoever and has had absolutely nothing to do with any policy proposals since we came to government-but I will continue this in a moment. (Time expired) relation to unemployment is: give us more time. Unemployment has gone from 8.5 per cent when we left office to 8.8 per cent now and the government says: give us more time. Given that when John Howard was Treasurer, he left us with unemployment at 10 per cent, does that mean that the electorate ought to give him time to bring unemployment up from 8.5 through 8.8 to 10 per cent? Plainly, the government has no answers in relation to unemployment. They have said 'Give us our industrial relations legislation.' They have said, 'Let us cut the budget. Let us implement all the reforms that we want to do.' Then they look around and say, 'Oh dear, unemployment has gone up. What are we going to do about it now? Are we going to introduce a GST?' It is always, 'Give us our agenda and then something will happen in relation to unemployment.' In fact, they have no answers in relation to unemployment. It is particularly severe in regional areas, with 12.9 per cent in Gippsland and 12.9 per cent in other areas of rural Victoria. The thing that I particularly want to put before the committee in consideration in detail is the future of the skillshares. I and other members have received correspondence from skillshares about where they will be left in this brave new employment services market world. The National Skillshare Association has pointed out: ... in the event that the government does not provide the advance payments we are seeking, the great majority of our more than 350 community organisation members will not be in a position to submit tenders for this important element of the new market. The inevitable consequence of this would be that

speaker: Mr Kelvin Thomson (Wills) (11.19 A.m.)
theText: What the government is saying to us in5922 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 many would be forced to cease operations altogether, with associated loss of valuable community infrastructure and dimunition of capacity, diversity and competition in the proposed market-particularly in terms of provision of assistance to the most disadvantaged unemployed people. We think it not unreasonable that the Government should set conditions for initial operation of the new market which recognise the particular and special circumstances of not-for-profit organisations and which give them a reasonable chance to adapt to the competitive environment the Government intends to create. We have had correspondence from the National Skillshare Association to the minister which says: Our own analysis of the financial parameters for providing employment assistance services under the terms set out in the Exposure Draft make it clear that even the most optimistic assumptions about client flows and outcomes achieved will still see organisations facing significant negative cash flows in the early stages of the operation of the market. They go on to say: It is entirely unreasonable for the government or the department to expect that the good citizens who comprise the Boards and Management Committees of sponsor organisations should expose themselves to the significant additional burdens and personal financial risks associated with borrowing funds so they can continue ... Similarly, Mr Deputy Speaker, we had correspondence from the Maylands skillshare. This is a Western Australian skillshare but it reflects the situation found by skillshares in my electorate and in other parts of the country that were set up by non-profit organisations. Maylands was set up by the Royal Western Australian Institute for the Blind. They point out that after February 1998 they will experience negative cash flows for at least three months until payments for the employment services provided are made. They say that, having had to operate as not-for-profit organisations, skillshares do not have any cash reserves, let alone substantial ones. It is little surprise against that background that the Royal Western Australian Institute for the Blind has made the decision that it is unable to underwrite the temporary negative cash flow-at this stage estimated to be in the range of $45,000 to $70,000-and this leads to a scenario of the pin being pulled on Maylands skillshare. As they point out, it will be repeated with many skillshare organisations all around Australia. Mr Deputy Speaker, I and a number of other members of parliament have also received correspondence from the north-east employment project where they have talked about Dr David Kemp's plan to spend $200 million on school based employment programs. They pose this question: is there any way in which Dr Kemp might be persuaded that effective, efficient notforprofit organisations already exist, at least in Victoria, to do exactly the job for which he proposes reinventing the wheel? That is exactly right. The abandonment of the CES-or the carve-up of the CES-in my view will lead to a disaster in terms of employment placement at the very time this community can least afford it. (Time expired) Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (11.24 a.m.)-I take up the member's point about skillshare. The government has a great deal of respect for the skillshare sector and my understanding is that negotiations are taking place between the skillshare sector and the department on the sorts of transitional issues that he raised. I want to go back briefly to the question raised by the member for Banks( Mr Melham) and the role of my former adviser. My former adviser left me on Friday9 May and the following
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Abbott (Warringah
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment,Thursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5923 Monday he appeared as the chief adviser to the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). I have to say that I regarded that as an act of treachery. I regarded that as an act of betrayal of me, of the local Liberal Party which gave him an enormous amount of support as the preselected candidate for Manly, and of a great many citizens of Manly who had reposed their trust and confidence in him. Mr Martin Ferguson-Was he in your faction? not-he would have been in the other faction. It was, if you like, as a way of handing an olive branch to others that he entered my office. in silence. phone calls. It became apparent that he had made dozens of phone calls on a departmental mobile phone, going back to late last year, to the member for Oxley and to David Ettridge. Obviously, these had absolutely nothing whatsoever to do with his duties as my staff member. They had absolutely nothing to do with his role in helping to liaise between the department and me. I wrote two letters to the departmental secretary seeking the investigation of those phone calls and seeking the recovery of any costs that were incurred that were not properly attributable to his work for me. I believe that those investigations are continuing. Not long after he left my office, I was contacted by David Thomas, a former employee of the member for Oxley, who let me know that while my former staffer was employed by me he had attended some functions which again had absolutely nothing to do with his employment by me or his work in liaising with the department, but had everything to do with the moonlighting he had been doing for the member for Oxley. I have also written to the Department of Administrative Services seeking an investigation of one trip and one section of another trip, because again I am absolutely determined to ensure that no costs will be incurred by the taxpayers for activities which helped to enable my former staffer to assist the member for Oxley. Obviously, the behaviour of my former staffer is hugely embarrassing for me and for the local Liberal Party, but it is also a real problem for the member for Oxley. The member for Oxley has taken onto her staff someone with so little sense of propriety, someone with so little sense of discretion about the use of government resources that he was prepared to use those government resources quite freely in ways which had nothing to do with his work for me as the member for Warringah, nothing to do with his work for the electors of Warringah, and nothing whatsoever to do with his work for the department. In fact, information provided by David Thomas suggests that not only did he do this when he was working for me but now that he is working for the member for Oxley, even though he is employed by her in her capacity as an independent member of parliament, he is working full-time on the establishment of the One Nation Party. This strikes me as being at odds with the spirit, if not the letter, of the provisions under which independent members get an extra staff entitlement. There are some very serious issues for the member for Oxley here. She preaches restraint in the use of government funds, but it is hard to see that it is being practised. So far, the

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: After he left my employ, I asked for a check to be made of his mobile5924 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 member for Oxley, as an independent, looks to resemble Senator Colston more than she does Ted Mack. in this discussion about these changes to support for young unemployed people is what they will do in terms of the shift between public and private education. The truth is that you inject large numbers of people into an education system where they know they are going to get no benefit, save that that is their only means of having income support and the only way in which their families can sustain their children with any form of commitment. The unemployment circumstances are such that they cannot find employment and this government is going to refuse them the opportunities to seek employment and to improve their employability through labour market programs or access to unemployment benefits. If you force those unwilling participants into an already overcrowded state education system, then people will naturally say that that will degrade that state education system. They will not be going into private education because they do not have the means. The only sector of the education system they will be able to access is the already overcrowded and underfunded state education system. That will then carry the baggage of unwilling participants. Teachers will be baby-sitting large numbers of people who will be getting no benefit and whose parents know they are getting no benefit. Those who wish to participate to gain benefit out of the education system will increasingly have to choose to fund their children's education in the private sector. As well as the natural damage that is occurring to Australia's families, we will get the pressure that this will place on family breakdown and the consequences it will mean for the impoverishment of many families who will not wish to force their children into this stupid position. As well as that, we will find that it will degrade the state education systems around Australia. Years 11 and 12 will be carrying unwilling, unwelcome participants. They will be therefore unattractive to people who have the funds to escape from those systems. They will move into the private education system. Increasingly, we get a two-tier system of education where you get quality education only if you pay for it. Of course, that is being matched with a funding regime that increasingly benefits those newly established independent schools. Schools will be established in places where there is no check that they will not damage the participation of the public educational sector and where the transfer costs, as they emerge, will gut the effectiveness of the public education system. What we are actually doing is trying to hide unemployment. This government is trying to hide unemployment by shifting it into forcing people into yean; 11 and 12 education when we, as the former government, had already increased participation to a degree which was hitherto unknown in Australia. We were actually getting people going through higher education. Now we will force unwilling participants, who will not be capable of benefiting from it, into that system. That will degrade that public education system. It will continue the transfer and shift of people out of public education into private education. A class-ridden outcome, where wealth dictates your success in life, emerges as the likely outcome. That is what you can predict as a result of these very stupid changes. The only motivating factor that underlies them is a desire to obscure the fact that this government has nothing to offer to young Australians, who they bleated about before the last election as being their object of primary concern. Before the last election, the high rate of unemployed in that sector who
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Kerr (Denison) (11.30 A.m.)
theText: One of the things of substance that has not emergedThursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5925 were not participating in the education system was identified as this government's number one priority. What do they do in government? They tum on those very people. They offer them no employment opportunities. They offer them no effective training opportunities. They park them in an educational system for which they cannot gain a benefit because that system is not designed to operate as a technical or further education system. It is not designed to increase job readiness. They will park them there, they will degrade that system's effectiveness, and they will increase the shift of people from the public sector to the private sector. This is retrograde and stupid as far as Australia's national interests are concerned. (Time expired) recent intervention by the parliamentary secretary and I can understand his feelings about treachery with respect to his former assistant, Mr Oldfield. He has raised very serious allegations today going to the operation of the parliament and the system of assistance, both to government and to the opposition, with respect to their staff. In that context, it is exceptionally important that he actually tables the correspondence that he has sent to the department setting out his allegations, so that the parliament at large and the Australian public understand the types of allegations he has detailed and required the department to investigate. It is only fair because I think that there is a genuine desire on both sides of the House at the moment to ensure full and proper parliamentary accountability with respect to the use of parliamentary entitlements. In that context, I fully appreciate why the parliamentary secretary is, if anything, really a little bit emotional with respect to these issues. I would feel the same way if it had occurred to me. So, I suggest that today, or at some date that is possible, the details of the allegations as set out in his correspondence be tabled because I think the parliament wants to know what is really at the bottom of this. The allegations that he has made today do not just go to his own staff; they also go to the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). I also want to touch briefly on questions raised by the parliamentary secretary relating to an overall budget strategy. I appreciate that there is no quick-fix on the issue of jobs. It is fair to say that both houses have different approaches but, from the Labor Party's point of view, it is appropriate that we detail what we regard as an appropriate strategy. It is a debate about ideas and not a question of a bottomless pit and throwing money at the unemployed. It goes to your capacity to generate economic growth-and I point the finger and suggest that a projected level of economic growth of 3.5 per cent is inadequate. That is not just my view; it is also the view of the Reserve Bank governor and the secretary of Treasury. I also suggest that economic growth alone is not necessary. It goes to government policy and to whether you have industry and regional policy-and I am pleased to say that the government actually embraced our automotive plan. We have paved the way and forced reform at an international level with respect to the globalisation of the economy and changes, for example, on the tariff front. But enough was enough. It was appropriate that both sides of the House came together on the Labor Party's industry plan for the automotive industry. But it extends beyond the automotive industry to a range of other industries. It then goes to the question of regional Australia. You need to intervene and assist in regional Australia. It also raises the question of services to regional Australia. If you care about jobs, it is not smart to sack 28,000 public servants in the first two budgets. That takes me to the final aspect of a program, having touched on briefly the issue of a trade policy. We have a pool of long-term unemployed. Unfortunately, more and more of those
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Martin Ferguson (Batman) (11.35 A.m.)
theText: I listened with interest to the most5926 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 people are in particular suburbs and regions. You have to have targeted decent labour market programs that you are prepared to invest in to try and get those people job ready, back into the discipline of work and back to work. We are prepared to debate the ideas. There is no quick-fix, but you have got to have a strategy. The problem with this government, I dare to suggest, is that it does not have a job strategy. It has a mind-set which extends beyond a role for government actually intervening and getting its hands dirty. It should be trying to facilitate, to push and prod, to attract investment, to create jobs and also to deliver those vital labour market programs that are so important to get people back into the discipline of work so that they have a capacity to change employers' attitudes to ensure that the employers finally accept that those people who could have been forgotten are worthy of employment. That is what it is about. We should not push them aside and forget them. We have to intervene and assist and invest in their future. They are worthy of employment; they deserve a second go. Green Corps is wrong. The majority of places have gone to people in employment and/or education. Our responsibility-that is, the responsibility of the parliament as a whole, irrespective of policy differences-is to accept that there is a role for government in assisting those people. (Time expired) Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (11.40 a.m.)-We have had a full debate on these issues, and I thank members opposite for their contributions. I would like to indicate that, as far as the government is concerned, the debate has canvassed the issues adequately. Finally, on the matters raised concerning the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), yes, she does have an important challenge to demonstrate just what kind of an independent member she is in respect of her attitude to public funds. Yes, on the suggestions before us, she may resemble Mal Colston more than she resembles Ted Mack. I want to say that the matters are being investigated. They are serious matters and, when those investigations are concluded, an appropriate statement will be made. I can give the member for Batman( Mr Martin Ferguson) that assurance. in relation to the comments of the member for Warringah ( Mr Abbott). It is not merely a matter, I would suggest, of referring matters in relation to the former employee for investigation and assessment. This is analogous to the situation that emerged in West Germany before East and West Germany merged, where it was discerned that Willy Brandt, when Chancellor, had had on his staff as one of his closest advisers a person who was working for and reporting to the East German authorities. When that fact was discerned, it was a matter not merely of how that had come to occur, what responsibility there was and what prosecution or action could be taken against that former employee who had betrayed the trust, but also of how the supervision and the character judgment of Willy Brandt was such as to have allowed that person to remain in that office for such a period of time and to carryon that activity under the nose of a person in Brandt's position. There are questions that actually go to Parliamentary Secretary Abbott's capacity, responsibility, supervision and management of his office. There is also the question of the degree to which he, ministers, other parliamentary secretaries and other members of the coalition parties may in fact have contributed to the situation through their failure to scrutinise the work that was being undertaken and also the character of, and the nature of the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Abbott (Warringah
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment,
title: Representatives Main Commiitee

speaker: Mr Kerr (Denison) (11.41 A.m.)
theText: I will follow up on a couple of matters that emergedThursday, 19 June 1997 MAIN COMMITTEE 5927 responsibilities being pursued by, people in their employment "iho were actually working for a social force that has properly been characterised now by the Prime Minister as analogous to the kind of disruptive force that has emerged in other countries to the great detriment of their social cohesion. That situation was occurring under the watch of the parliamentary secretary, and we do not know whether similar practices are occurring with respect to any other coalition members, parliamentary secretaries or ministers. This goes also to a further question relating to the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). If she was knowingly the beneficiary of work that was being performed by somebody who was on the payroll of another member of parliament, and if she was drawing from that a benefit to which she was not entitled, that is plainly analogous to a form of corruption of the process. It is a form of corruption because it goes to taking that which you know you are not entitled to-by reason of the fact that it was being paid for in order to be supportive of, in this case, the parliamentary secretary at the table. It is analogous to drawing from another member of parliament part of their postal entitlement or any other entitlement to which you yourself are not entitled. So, there are questions that go to the knowledge and the participation of those in the office of the member for Oxley. Those are fundamentally important questions. Has the parliamentary secretary asked that those matters also be pursued? If not, why not? Why have those matters not been sought to be put to the test? I would also ask the parliamentary secretary why his judgment of the character of those working for him was so remiss. What steps did he put in place to select people who were fit to occupy the office that he entrusted them to hold within his staff? It is not a matter you can brush off by saying, 'These people betrayed me.' From what the parliamentary secretary has indicated to date, there plainly was a long history of deceit. What was it that was so slack about his management of his office? What steps are in place to ensure that this does not happen in other circumstances where there may be people who are actually letting down those who have placed trust in them? What are the staffing processes that those in ministerial and other executive positions, including parliamentary secretaries, undertake to make certain that they are not appointing people'to positions of high responsibility who will, as occurred in Germany, betray them. When that occurred in Germany, the criticism fell on Willy Brandt for his failure to manage his office, as much as it did on the betrayal of those on his staff. There are two questions there: what were the circumstances whereby your scrutiny of your own office was so deficient; and, secondly, what steps, if any, have you asked to be undertaken with respect to the member for Oxley's participation? (Time expired) Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (11.46 a.m.)-The member for Denison( Mr Kerr) does raise two important issues. The sad truth is that it is impossible to control what members of one's staff do in their own time and outside of one's own office. I think I can give the chamber an assurance that none of the misdeeds of my former staff member took place in my office, certainly not in office hours, for the simple reason that it is an open plan office and anything untoward would immediately have been noticed by the other staff members who were sitting around him. The misdeeds took place out of the office and on the mobile phone, to the best of my knowledge, and I think I can reasonably make the assumption that that is the case. The member for Denison also says, 'How on earth could I have possibly employed this person?' Yes, that is also a fair question. AllI say in my defence is that this individual was able to persuade a majority of a Liberal Party preselection panel-and it was not in a hard
title: Representatives Main Commiitee

speaker: Mr Abbott (Warringah
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment,5928 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 19 June 1997 luck seat which no-one wants to run in, like Oxley, but a state seat which was traditionally a Liberal seat. It was a hotly contested preselection, he emerged victorious and I guess I took the view that anyone who was good enough for the Liberal Party at that level would probably be an appropriate person for me. He was also a member of Manly Council, elected by the people of Manly. SoI think I had reasonable grounds for assuming that the man was competent, capable and trustworthy. Certainly there is no denying his competence. It is just that what he did while in my office over the last few months of his employment was an act of treachery. relation to a particular staff member whose salary was not covered by the estimates under debate would need to be relevant to the issues before the chamber. of what process does apply with respect to character checks of staff being employed by the executive? As minister for justice under the former government, I am aware, because I had some managerial and supervisory role in relation to this, that staff were required to be vetted not merely by those who recommended their appointment in the first place but ultimately, including when security issues and other issues were of concern, by officers of ASIO, for example, in relation to security vetting. These were checks that were built into the employment system. I acknowledge, with respect to the former government, that there were occasions between the appointment process and the completion of those checks when those vetting processes were not taking place. But those checks would deal with associates and a whole range of other issues and would go to character and a whole associated raft of issues. I wonder whether, if not necessarily now, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs( Mr Abbott) could take on notice whether or not those same arrangements still apply, and, if not, what arrangements are in place to ensure that mistakes are not made simply because somebody has a seemingly good public reputation yet may have participated in a way which could ultimately be very damaging to the interests of the Commonwealth of Australia. This is simply an interest where your political interests have been damaged significantly because of that betrayal. But, potentially, a failure to assess the character and fitness for service of an employee of the executive could have much more significant security and other national consequences were that betrayal not to another political party but, for example, to another nation. I simply ask that that question be addressed. Education, Training and Youth Affairs) (11.50 a.m.)-My understanding is that the same kinds of vetting processes are in place now as were in place under the former government. Warringah ( Mr Abbott) in relation to this debate and in terms of employment. The government's forecast of economic growth in the budget is at 3.75 per cent. It is that that concerns me with the government's attitude and the parliamentary secretary's attitude, 'Let's have a bit of patience. Let's wait, things will get better,' but 3.75 per cent growth is not enough to pick up newcomers to the marketplace into job opportunities. In our last couple of years of government we exceeded those growth rates. That is why this government piggybacked in on young people's fear of job opportunities that they thought were vanishing.
